Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Establishment of a Virtual Sponsored Research Office
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description
This project will support a planning process to establish a Virtual Sponsored Research Office (VSRO). The concept of the VSRO is for it to be a shared resource to assist faculty and administrators at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) in preparing and submitting proposals to the NSF and other federal agencies and provide training in the appropriate policies and procedures for managing federal awards. HBCUs have struggled to improve their competitive research standing, in part due to the challenges faced by their administrators who are facing increased demands from both federal agencies and faculty investigators while lacking the critical infrastructure needed to keep up with the rising demands. The vision of the VSRO is to develop an innovative online platform to provide support services to HBCU institutional ?clients?. This service would address the needs of small and mid-size HBCUs that do not currently have adequate sponsored research capabilities.

Technical Description
The planning activity wwill solicit input from the community of HBCU researchers and administrators via a series of virtual meetings and in-person workshops. From these activities the project team will complete a comprehensive needs assessment for the participating institutions and then determine what combination of products and services would best meet these community needs. All aspects of proposal development and post-award management will be considered throughout the planning process, including but not limited to issues related to intellectual property and human subjects research. It is expected that this planning process will ultimately lead to the development of a proposal to implement the VSRO concept.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through support from the National Science Foundation's "The Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR)" Program, a partnership led by Tuskegee University has established a state-of-the-art Virtual Sponsored Research Office (VSRO) to assist Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) faculty members at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) in the preparation of competitive proposals. The rationale behind the VSRO is to raise the competitive standing in grantsmanship at HBCUs through virtual mentoring, support and subject matter guidance. All activities related to proposal development are performed electronically for efficiency and for future scalability. The project focuses its efforts on those HBCUs that are located within the ESPSCoR jurisdiction.

The VSRO interactive platform divides the proposal development work in two phases. Firstly, a short White Paper describing the main concepts and ideas is prepared by faculty members (proposers) at HBCUs in response to program solicitations. This White Paper is matched by the VSRO platform to discipline experts called "Red Team" members who review the document and provide feedback to the proposers. This matching is done solely based on the keywords that describe the White Paper and the keywords associated with the background of the Red Team members. The feedback from the Red Team members is used by the proposers during the second phase of the writing process consisting of the development of the full proposal, which is also reviewed by the Red Team. This mentoring provided by the Red Team is intended to help proposers from HBCUs overcome the lack of support in proposal development at these institutions (e.g. little to no start-up funds) which is often available at more research intensive institutions.

Outcomes of this project include a fully functional VSRO interactive platform equipped with a rich database of Red Team members. Several faculty members at HBCUs from EPSCoR states have experienced the virtual support that is offered by the VSRO through workshops organized under this planning grant.  Additionally, several HBCUs in the Southeast, including those from the states of Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee and the Virgin Islands have expressed the need and an appreciation for the VSRO platform that has been developed through the NSF EPSCoR funding.


Last Modified: 11/03/2019
Modified by: Mohammed A Qazi
